config.text: What will happen to your car when you drive up a steep hill?

choices.label: The high gears will pull better
The steering will feel heavier
Overtaking will be easier
The engine will work harder

correct.text: The engine will need more power to pull the vehicle up the hill. When approaching a steep hill you should select a lower gear to help maintain your speed. You should do this without hesitation, so that you don’t lose too much speed before engaging the lower gear.

incorrect.text: The engine will need more power to pull the vehicle up the hill. When approaching a steep hill you should select a lower gear to help maintain your speed. You should do this without hesitation, so that you don’t lose too much speed before engaging the lower gear.

config.text: Which lights must you use if you're driving on a well-lit motorway at night?

choices.label: Use only your sidelights
Use your headlights
Use rear fog lights
Use front fog lights

correct.text: If you’re driving on a motorway at night or in poor visibility, you must always use your headlights, even if the road is well lit. Other road users must be able to see you, but you should avoid causing dazzle.

incorrect.text: If you’re driving on a motorway at night or in poor visibility, you must always use your headlights, even if the road is well lit. Other road users must be able to see you, but you should avoid causing dazzle.

config.text: What's a rumble device designed to do?

choices.label: Give directions
Prevent cattle escaping
Alert you to low tyre pressure
Alert you to a hazard

correct.text: A rumble device consists of raised markings or strips, designed to give drivers an audible, visual and tactile warning. These devices are used in various locations, including in the line separating the hard shoulder and the left-hand lane on the motorway and on the approach to some hazards, to alert drivers to the need to slow down.

incorrect.text: A rumble device consists of raised markings or strips, designed to give drivers an audible, visual and tactile warning. These devices are used in various locations, including in the line separating the hard shoulder and the left-hand lane on the motorway and on the approach to some hazards, to alert drivers to the need to slow down.

config.text: What should you do if you park on the road when it's foggy?

choices.label: Leave parking lights switched on
Leave dipped headlights and fog lights switched on
Leave dipped headlights switched on
Leave main-beam headlights switched on

correct.text: If you have to park your vehicle in foggy conditions, try to find a place to park off the road. If this isn’t possible, park on the road facing in the same direction as the traffic. Leave your parking lights switched on and make sure they're clean.

incorrect.text: If you have to park your vehicle in foggy conditions, try to find a place to park off the road. If this isn’t possible, park on the road facing in the same direction as the traffic. Leave your parking lights switched on and make sure they're clean.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC r174, KYTS p80

config.text: When may you wait in a box junction?

choices.label: When you're stationary in a queue of traffic
When approaching a pelican crossing
When approaching a zebra crossing
When oncoming traffic prevents you turning right

correct.text:
The purpose of a box junction is to keep the junction clear by preventing vehicles from stopping in the path of crossing traffic.
You mustn't enter a box junction unless your exit is clear. However, you may enter the box and wait if you want to turn right and are only prevented from doing so by oncoming traffic.

incorrect.text:
The purpose of a box junction is to keep the junction clear by preventing vehicles from stopping in the path of crossing traffic.
You mustn't enter a box junction unless your exit is clear. However, you may enter the box and wait if you want to turn right and are only prevented from doing so by oncoming traffic.

config.text: Why would you fit chains to your wheels?

choices.label: To help prevent damage to the road surface
To help prevent wear to the tyres
To help prevent skidding in deep snow
To help prevent the brakes locking

correct.text: Chains can be fitted to your wheels in snowy conditions. They can help you to move off without wheelspin, or to keep moving in deep snow. You'll still need to adjust your driving to suit these conditions.

incorrect.text: Chains can be fitted to your wheels in snowy conditions. They can help you to move off without wheelspin, or to keep moving in deep snow. You'll still need to adjust your driving to suit these conditions.

config.text: What should you do when you're driving along a road that has a series of road humps?

choices.label: Brake firmly when you reach each road hump
Vary your speed between each road hump
Stay at a reduced speed for the whole stretch of road
Set your car's cruise control

correct.text: Traffic-calming measures are designed to protect vulnerable road users. Keep your speed down where traffic-calming measures are in place.

incorrect.text: Traffic-calming measures are designed to protect vulnerable road users. Keep your speed down where traffic-calming measures are in place.

config.text: What will happen if you hold the clutch pedal down or roll in neutral for too long?

choices.label: It will use more fuel
It will cause the engine to overheat
It will reduce your control
It will improve tyre wear

correct.text: Holding the clutch down or staying in neutral for too long will cause your vehicle to freewheel. This is known as 'coasting' and it's dangerous because it reduces your control of the vehicle.

incorrect.text: Holding the clutch down or staying in neutral for too long will cause your vehicle to freewheel. This is known as 'coasting' and it's dangerous because it reduces your control of the vehicle.

config.text: There's been a heavy fall of snow. What should you consider before driving in these conditions?

choices.label: Whether you should fit an amber flashing beacon to your car
Whether you should drive without wearing your seat belt
Whether you should wear sunglasses to reduce the glare
Whether your journey is essential

correct.text: Consider whether the increased risk is worth it. If the weather conditions are bad and your journey isn’t essential, then don't drive. If you have to drive, make sure you're well prepared in case you get stuck.

incorrect.text: Consider whether the increased risk is worth it. If the weather conditions are bad and your journey isn’t essential, then don't drive. If you have to drive, make sure you're well prepared in case you get stuck.

meta.xref: DES s12, HC r114, HC r226

config.text: What will happen if you use rear fog lights in good conditions?

choices.label: They'll make it safer when towing a trailer
They'll protect you from larger vehicles
They'll dazzle other drivers
They'll make drivers behind keep back

correct.text: Rear fog lights shine more brightly than normal rear lights, so that they show up in reduced visibility. When the visibility improves, you must switch them off; this stops them dazzling the driver behind.

incorrect.text: Rear fog lights shine more brightly than normal rear lights, so that they show up in reduced visibility. When the visibility improves, you must switch them off; this stops them dazzling the driver behind.

config.text: What should you do when you're overtaking at night?

choices.label: Wait until a bend so that you can see oncoming headlights
Sound your horn twice before moving out
Go past slowly so that you can react to unseen hazards
Beware of bends in the road ahead

correct.text: Don't overtake if there’s a possibility of a road junction, bend or brow of a bridge or hill ahead. There are many hazards that are difficult to see in the dark. Only overtake if you’re certain that the road ahead is clear. Don’t take a chance.

incorrect.text: Don't overtake if there’s a possibility of a road junction, bend or brow of a bridge or hill ahead. There are many hazards that are difficult to see in the dark. Only overtake if you’re certain that the road ahead is clear. Don’t take a chance.

meta.xref: DES s12, HC r114, HC r226, HC r236

config.text: You've been driving in fog. What must you do when the visibility improves?

choices.label: Switch off your fog lights
Keep your rear fog lights switched on
Keep your front fog lights switched on
Leave your fog lights switched on in case the fog returns

correct.text: You must turn off your fog lights if visibility is more than 100 metres (328 feet). Be prepared for the fact that the fog may be patchy and you may need to turn them on again if the fog returns.

incorrect.text: You must turn off your fog lights if visibility is more than 100 metres (328 feet). Be prepared for the fact that the fog may be patchy and you may need to turn them on again if the fog returns.

config.text: Why could it be dangerous to keep the clutch down, or select neutral, for long periods of time while you're driving?

choices.label: Fuel spillage will occur
Engine damage may be caused
You'll have less steering and braking control
It will wear tyres out more quickly

correct.text: Letting your vehicle roll or coast in neutral reduces your control over steering and braking. This can be dangerous on downhill slopes, where your vehicle could pick up speed very quickly.

incorrect.text: Letting your vehicle roll or coast in neutral reduces your control over steering and braking. This can be dangerous on downhill slopes, where your vehicle could pick up speed very quickly.

config.text: What should you do if you have to make a journey in foggy conditions?

choices.label: Follow other vehicles’ tail lights closely
Avoid using dipped headlights
Leave plenty of time for your journey
Keep two seconds behind the vehicle ahead

correct.text: If you’re planning to make a journey when it’s foggy, listen to the weather reports. If visibility is very poor, avoid making unnecessary journeys. If you do travel, leave plenty of time – and if someone is waiting for you to arrive, let them know that your journey will take longer than normal. This will also take off any pressure you may feel to rush.

incorrect.text: If you’re planning to make a journey when it’s foggy, listen to the weather reports. If visibility is very poor, avoid making unnecessary journeys. If you do travel, leave plenty of time – and if someone is waiting for you to arrive, let them know that your journey will take longer than normal. This will also take off any pressure you may feel to rush.

config.text: What should you check before you start a journey in foggy weather?

choices.label: The radiator has enough anti-freeze
You have a warning triangle in the vehicle
The windows and lights are clean and clear
You have a mobile phone with you

correct.text: If you have to drive in fog, switch your dipped headlights on and keep all your windows clear. You should always be able to pull up within the distance you can see ahead.

incorrect.text: If you have to drive in fog, switch your dipped headlights on and keep all your windows clear. You should always be able to pull up within the distance you can see ahead.

config.text: Why is it bad technique to coast when you're driving downhill?

choices.label: The fuel consumption will increase
The engine will overheat
The tyres will wear more quickly
The vehicle will gain speed more quickly

correct.text: Coasting is when you allow the vehicle to freewheel in neutral or with the clutch pedal depressed. When travelling downhill, this will cause the vehicle to gain speed more quickly as you lose the benefits of engine braking; it may even lead to a loss of control. You shouldn't coast, especially when approaching hazards such as junctions or bends and when travelling downhill.

incorrect.text: Coasting is when you allow the vehicle to freewheel in neutral or with the clutch pedal depressed. When travelling downhill, this will cause the vehicle to gain speed more quickly as you lose the benefits of engine braking; it may even lead to a loss of control. You shouldn't coast, especially when approaching hazards such as junctions or bends and when travelling downhill.

meta.xref: DES s11, DES s12, HC r232

config.text: You're driving on the motorway in windy conditions. What should you do as you overtake a high-sided vehicle?

choices.label: Increase your speed
Be wary of a sudden gust
Drive alongside very closely
Expect normal conditions

correct.text: The draught caused by other vehicles – particularly those with high sides – could be strong enough to push you out of your lane. Be prepared for a sudden gust of wind as you overtake large vehicles. Keep both hands on the steering wheel to help you keep full control.

incorrect.text: The draught caused by other vehicles – particularly those with high sides – could be strong enough to push you out of your lane. Be prepared for a sudden gust of wind as you overtake large vehicles. Keep both hands on the steering wheel to help you keep full control.

config.text: What should you do when dealing with this hazard?

choices.label: Switch on your hazard warning lights
Use a low gear and drive slowly
Use a high gear to prevent wheelspin
Switch on your windscreen wipers

correct.text: In normal conditions, a ford can be crossed quite safely by driving through it slowly. The water may affect your brakes, so when you're clear of the ford, test them before you resume normal driving.

incorrect.text: In normal conditions, a ford can be crossed quite safely by driving through it slowly. The water may affect your brakes, so when you're clear of the ford, test them before you resume normal driving.

config.text: You're driving at night. What should you do if you're dazzled by headlights coming towards you?

choices.label: Pull down your sun visor
Slow down or stop
Flash your main-beam headlights
Shade your eyes with your hand

correct.text: If the headlights of an oncoming vehicle dazzle you, slow down or, if necessary, stop. Don’t close your eyes or swerve, as you'll increase your chances of having a collision. Don't flash your headlights either, as this could dazzle other drivers and make the situation worse.

incorrect.text: If the headlights of an oncoming vehicle dazzle you, slow down or, if necessary, stop. Don’t close your eyes or swerve, as you'll increase your chances of having a collision. Don't flash your headlights either, as this could dazzle other drivers and make the situation worse.

meta.xref: DES s12, HC r114, HC r226

config.text: Why should you switch off your rear fog lights when the fog has cleared?

choices.label: To allow your headlights to work
To stop draining the battery
To stop the engine losing power
To prevent dazzling drivers behind

correct.text: Don’t forget to switch off your fog lights when the weather improves. You could be prosecuted for driving with them on in good visibility. The high intensity of rear fog lights can dazzle drivers behind and make your brake lights difficult to notice.

incorrect.text: Don’t forget to switch off your fog lights when the weather improves. You could be prosecuted for driving with them on in good visibility. The high intensity of rear fog lights can dazzle drivers behind and make your brake lights difficult to notice.

config.text: The road is wet. Why would a motorcyclist steer around drain covers while they were cornering?

choices.label: To avoid puncturing the tyres on the edge of the drain covers
To prevent the motorcycle sliding on the metal drain covers
To help judge the bend using the drain covers as marker points
To avoid splashing pedestrians on the pavement

correct.text: Other drivers or riders may have to change course due to the size or characteristics of their vehicle. Understanding this will help you to anticipate their actions. Motorcyclists and cyclists will be checking the road ahead for uneven or slippery surfaces, especially in wet weather. They may need to move across their lane to avoid surface hazards such as potholes and drain covers.

incorrect.text: Other drivers or riders may have to change course due to the size or characteristics of their vehicle. Understanding this will help you to anticipate their actions. Motorcyclists and cyclists will be checking the road ahead for uneven or slippery surfaces, especially in wet weather. They may need to move across their lane to avoid surface hazards such as potholes and drain covers.

config.text: What's the reason for traffic-calming measures?

choices.label: To stop road rage
To make overtaking easier
To slow traffic down
To make parking easier

correct.text: Traffic-calming measures make the roads safer for vulnerable road users, such as cyclists, pedestrians and children. These can be designed as chicanes, road humps or other obstacles that encourage drivers and riders to slow down.

incorrect.text: Traffic-calming measures make the roads safer for vulnerable road users, such as cyclists, pedestrians and children. These can be designed as chicanes, road humps or other obstacles that encourage drivers and riders to slow down.

meta.xref: DES s12, HC r114, HC r226

config.text: You're driving with your front fog lights switched on. What should you do if the fog has cleared?

choices.label: Leave them on if other drivers have their lights on
Switch them off as long as visibility remains good
Flash them to warn oncoming traffic that it's foggy
Drive with them on instead of your headlights

correct.text: Switch off your fog lights if the weather improves, but be prepared to use them again if visibility reduces to less than 100 metres (328 feet).

incorrect.text: Switch off your fog lights if the weather improves, but be prepared to use them again if visibility reduces to less than 100 metres (328 feet).

config.text: When may you overtake another vehicle on their left?

choices.label: When you’re in a one-way street
When approaching a motorway slip road where you’ll be turning off
When the vehicle in front is signalling to turn left
When a slower vehicle is travelling in the right-hand lane of a dual carriageway

correct.text: You may pass slower vehicles on their left while travelling along a one-way street. Be aware of drivers who may need to change lanes and may not expect faster traffic passing on their left.

incorrect.text: You may pass slower vehicles on their left while travelling along a one-way street. Be aware of drivers who may need to change lanes and may not expect faster traffic passing on their left.

config.text: When will you feel the effects of engine braking?

choices.label: When you only use the parking brake
When you're in neutral
When you change to a lower gear
When you change to a higher gear

correct.text: You will feel the effect of engine braking when you take your foot off the accelerator. Changing to a lower gear will increase the effect.

incorrect.text: You will feel the effect of engine braking when you take your foot off the accelerator. Changing to a lower gear will increase the effect.

config.text: Why should you reduce your speed when you're driving or riding in fog?

choices.label: The brakes don't work as well
You'll be dazzled by other headlights
The engine will take longer to warm up
It's more difficult to see what's ahead

correct.text:
You won’t be able to see as far ahead in fog as you can on a clear day. You'll need to reduce your speed so that, if a hazard looms out of the fog, you have the time and space to take avoiding action.
Travelling in fog is hazardous. If you can, try to delay your journey until it has cleared.

incorrect.text:
You won’t be able to see as far ahead in fog as you can on a clear day. You'll need to reduce your speed so that, if a hazard looms out of the fog, you have the time and space to take avoiding action.
Travelling in fog is hazardous. If you can, try to delay your journey until it has cleared.

config.text: Why are vehicles fitted with rear fog lights?

choices.label: To make them more visible when driving at high speed
To show when they've broken down in a dangerous position
To make them more visible in thick fog
To warn drivers following closely to drop back

correct.text: Rear fog lights make it easier to spot a vehicle ahead in foggy conditions. Avoid the temptation to use other vehicles' lights as a guide, as they may give you a false sense of security.

incorrect.text: Rear fog lights make it easier to spot a vehicle ahead in foggy conditions. Avoid the temptation to use other vehicles' lights as a guide, as they may give you a false sense of security.

config.text: Why is travelling in neutral for long distances (known as coasting) bad driving technique?

choices.label: It will cause the car to skid
It will make the engine stall
The engine will run faster
There won't be any engine braking

correct.text: Try to look and plan well ahead. Plan your approach to hazards and select the correct gear in good time. This will help give you the control you need to deal with anything unexpected that may occur.

incorrect.text: Try to look and plan well ahead. Plan your approach to hazards and select the correct gear in good time. This will help give you the control you need to deal with anything unexpected that may occur.

config.text: Which plate may appear with this road sign?

correct.text:
Road humps are used to slow down traffic. They're found in places where there are often pedestrians, such as
  • shopping areas
  • near schools
  • residential areas.
Watch out for people close to the kerb or crossing the road.

incorrect.text:
Road humps are used to slow down traffic. They're found in places where there are often pedestrians, such as
  • shopping areas
  • near schools
  • residential areas.
Watch out for people close to the kerb or crossing the road.

config.text: Why should you test your brakes after this hazard?

choices.label: You'll be on a slippery road
Your brakes will be wet
You'll be going down a long hill
You'll have just crossed a long bridge

correct.text: A ford is a crossing over a stream that’s shallow enough to drive or ride through. After you’ve gone through a ford or deep puddle, your brakes will be wet and they won't work as well as usual. To dry them out, apply a light brake pressure while moving slowly. Don’t travel at normal speeds until you're sure your brakes are working properly again.

incorrect.text: A ford is a crossing over a stream that’s shallow enough to drive or ride through. After you’ve gone through a ford or deep puddle, your brakes will be wet and they won't work as well as usual. To dry them out, apply a light brake pressure while moving slowly. Don’t travel at normal speeds until you're sure your brakes are working properly again.

config.text: Which lights should you switch on when daytime visibility is poor but not seriously reduced?

choices.label: Headlights and fog lights
Front fog lights
Dipped headlights
Rear fog lights

correct.text: Only use your fog lights when visibility is seriously reduced. Use dipped headlights in poor conditions because this helps other road users to see you without the risk of causing dazzle.

incorrect.text: Only use your fog lights when visibility is seriously reduced. Use dipped headlights in poor conditions because this helps other road users to see you without the risk of causing dazzle.

config.text: You're driving in fog. Why should you keep well back from the vehicle in front?

choices.label: In case it changes direction suddenly
In case its fog lights dazzle you
In case it stops suddenly
In case its brake lights dazzle you

correct.text: If you’re following another road user in fog, stay well back. The driver in front won’t be able to see hazards until they’re close and might need to brake suddenly. Also, the road surface is likely to be wet and could be slippery.

incorrect.text: If you’re following another road user in fog, stay well back. The driver in front won’t be able to see hazards until they’re close and might need to brake suddenly. Also, the road surface is likely to be wet and could be slippery.

config.text: You're travelling in very heavy rain. How is this likely to affect your overall stopping distance?

choices.label: It will be doubled
It will be halved
It will be ten times greater
It will be no different

correct.text: The road will be very wet and spray from other vehicles will reduce your visibility. Tyre grip will also be reduced, increasing your stopping distance. You should at least double your separation distance to make sure you can stop safely in the space you've allowed.

incorrect.text: The road will be very wet and spray from other vehicles will reduce your visibility. Tyre grip will also be reduced, increasing your stopping distance. You should at least double your separation distance to make sure you can stop safely in the space you've allowed.

meta.xref: DES s12, HC r114, HC r226

config.text: When may front fog lights be used?

choices.label: When visibility is seriously reduced
When they're fitted above the bumper
When they aren't as bright as the headlights
When an audible warning device is used

correct.text: Your fog lights must only be used when visibility is reduced to 100 metres (328 feet) or less. You need to be familiar with the layout of your dashboard so you're aware if your fog lights have been switched on in error, or you've forgotten to switch them off.

incorrect.text: Your fog lights must only be used when visibility is reduced to 100 metres (328 feet) or less. You need to be familiar with the layout of your dashboard so you're aware if your fog lights have been switched on in error, or you've forgotten to switch them off.

config.text: What must you do when you're overtaking a car at night?

choices.label: Flash your headlights before overtaking
Select a higher gear
Switch your headlights to main beam before overtaking
Make sure you don't dazzle other road users

correct.text: To prevent your headlights from dazzling the driver of the car in front, wait until you’ve passed them before switching to main beam.

incorrect.text: To prevent your headlights from dazzling the driver of the car in front, wait until you’ve passed them before switching to main beam.

config.text: What will affect your vehicle's stopping distance?

choices.label: The speed limit
The street lighting
The time of day
The condition of the tyres

correct.text: Having tyres correctly inflated and in good condition will ensure they have maximum grip on the road; how well your tyres grip the road has a significant effect on your car's stopping distance.

incorrect.text: Having tyres correctly inflated and in good condition will ensure they have maximum grip on the road; how well your tyres grip the road has a significant effect on your car's stopping distance.

meta.xref: DES s12, HC r115, HC r226

config.text: When must you use dipped headlights during the day?

choices.label: All the time you're driving
When you're driving along narrow streets
When you're driving in poor visibility
When you're parking

correct.text: You must use dipped headlights when daytime visibility is seriously reduced, generally to 100 metres (328 feet) or less. You may also use front or rear fog lights, but they must be switched off when visibility improves.

incorrect.text: You must use dipped headlights when daytime visibility is seriously reduced, generally to 100 metres (328 feet) or less. You may also use front or rear fog lights, but they must be switched off when visibility improves.

meta.xref: DES s5, DES s7, HC r160

config.text: How can you use your vehicle's engine to control your speed?

choices.label: By changing to a lower gear
By selecting reverse gear
By changing to a higher gear
By selecting neutral

correct.text: You should brake and slow down before selecting a lower gear. The gear can then be used to keep the speed low and help you control the vehicle. This is particularly helpful on long downhill stretches, where brake fade can occur if the brakes overheat.

incorrect.text: You should brake and slow down before selecting a lower gear. The gear can then be used to keep the speed low and help you control the vehicle. This is particularly helpful on long downhill stretches, where brake fade can occur if the brakes overheat.

config.text: You're travelling on a road that has road humps. What should you do when the driver in front is travelling more slowly than you?

choices.label: Sound your horn
Overtake as soon as you can
Flash your headlights
Slow down and stay behind

correct.text: Be patient and stay behind the car in front. You shouldn't normally overtake other vehicles in areas subject to traffic calming. If you overtake here, you may easily exceed the speed limit, defeating the purpose of the traffic-calming measures.

incorrect.text: Be patient and stay behind the car in front. You shouldn't normally overtake other vehicles in areas subject to traffic calming. If you overtake here, you may easily exceed the speed limit, defeating the purpose of the traffic-calming measures.

config.text: You're driving on a motorway at night. Which lights should you have on if there are other vehicles just ahead of you?

choices.label: Front fog lights
Main-beam headlights
Sidelights only
Dipped headlights

correct.text: If you’re driving behind other traffic on the motorway at night, use dipped headlights. Main-beam headlights will dazzle the other drivers. Your headlights’ dipped beam should fall short of the vehicle in front.

incorrect.text: If you’re driving behind other traffic on the motorway at night, use dipped headlights. Main-beam headlights will dazzle the other drivers. Your headlights’ dipped beam should fall short of the vehicle in front.

config.text: What colour are the reflective studs along the left-hand edge of the motorway?

choices.label: Green
Amber
Red
White

correct.text:
Reflective studs are used to help you in poor visibility. Different colours are used so that you’ll know which lane you're in. These are
  • red on the left-hand edge of the carriageway
  • white between lanes
  • amber on the right-hand edge of the carriageway
  • green between the carriageway and slip roads.

incorrect.text:
Reflective studs are used to help you in poor visibility. Different colours are used so that you’ll know which lane you're in. These are
  • red on the left-hand edge of the carriageway
  • white between lanes
  • amber on the right-hand edge of the carriageway
  • green between the carriageway and slip roads.

config.text: What should you do when you meet an oncoming vehicle on a single-track road?

choices.label: Reverse back to the main road
Carry out an emergency stop
Stop at a passing place
Switch on your hazard warning lights

correct.text: Take care when using single-track roads. It can be difficult to see around bends, because of hedges or fences, so expect to meet oncoming vehicles. Drive carefully and be ready to pull into or stop opposite a passing place, where you can pass each other safely.

incorrect.text: Take care when using single-track roads. It can be difficult to see around bends, because of hedges or fences, so expect to meet oncoming vehicles. Drive carefully and be ready to pull into or stop opposite a passing place, where you can pass each other safely.

meta.xref: DES s12, HC r114, HC r226

config.text: Why is it dangerous to leave rear fog lights switched on after the fog has cleared?

choices.label: They may be confused with brake lights
The bulbs would fail
Electrical systems could be overloaded
Direction indicators may not work properly

correct.text: If your rear fog lights are left on when it isn’t foggy, the glare they cause makes it difficult for road users behind to know whether you’re braking or you’ve just forgotten to turn off your rear fog lights. This can be a particular problem on wet roads and on motorways. If you leave your rear fog lights on at night, road users behind you are likely to be dazzled and this could put them at risk.

incorrect.text: If your rear fog lights are left on when it isn’t foggy, the glare they cause makes it difficult for road users behind to know whether you’re braking or you’ve just forgotten to turn off your rear fog lights. This can be a particular problem on wet roads and on motorways. If you leave your rear fog lights on at night, road users behind you are likely to be dazzled and this could put them at risk.

config.text: What's the purpose of the yellow lines painted across the road?

choices.label: To show a safe distance between vehicles
To keep the area clear of traffic
To make you aware of your speed
To warn you to change direction

correct.text: These lines may be painted on the road on the approach to a roundabout, a village or a particular hazard. The lines are raised and painted yellow, and their purpose is to make you aware of your speed. Reduce your speed in good time so that you avoid having to brake harshly over the last few metres before reaching the junction.

incorrect.text: These lines may be painted on the road on the approach to a roundabout, a village or a particular hazard. The lines are raised and painted yellow, and their purpose is to make you aware of your speed. Reduce your speed in good time so that you avoid having to brake harshly over the last few metres before reaching the junction.

config.text: You're driving on an icy road. What distance from the car in front should you drive?

choices.label: Four times the normal distance
Six times the normal distance
Eight times the normal distance
Ten times the normal distance

correct.text:
Don't travel in icy or snowy weather unless your journey is essential.
Drive extremely carefully when roads are or may be icy. Stopping distances can be ten times greater than on dry roads.

incorrect.text:
Don't travel in icy or snowy weather unless your journey is essential.
Drive extremely carefully when roads are or may be icy. Stopping distances can be ten times greater than on dry roads.
